verbs.description: colonize (third-person singular simple present colonizes, present participle colonizing, simple past and past participle colonized)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To settle (a place) with colonists, and hence make (a place) into a colony.
(transitive) To settle (a group of people, a species, or the like) in a place as a colony.
examples: When you are colonized by dangerous bacteria their presence in your body does no damage. You become a reservoir for those little stinkers.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To settle among and establish control over (the indigenous people of an area).
examples: The administration finally sent a naval vessel to return the 368 survivors to the United States in 1864. This ended official efforts to colonize blacks.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To begin a colony or colonies.
(transitive, social sciences, by extension) To intrude into and take over (the autonomy, experience, social movement, etc, of a less powerful person or group); to commandeer or appropriate.
examples: "To have our grief colonized to facilitate a racist political agenda was beyond offensive."
